Given that the approval rating at this moment is 41.3%, then my forecast is capped at 50%. Prior to the most recent polls, however, his approval rating hovered around 40.2%-40.5% for a few weeks, and there does not seem to be any recent major events that support a rise in his approval rating. This would indicate a higher than 33% chance, but as pointed out by several comments, Rasmussen polls are likely to be added to the 538 model soon, and those polls, which have significant weight in 538's model, have shown increasing approval ratings. This more than counterbalances the "stickiness" of Trump's previous approval ratings, so I assign my final probability as 30%, where I believe there is more volatility than the current crowd forecast of 25% seems to indicate, but assign a lower probability than I would have predicted before I updated on the information about Rasmussen polls.

Using a daily standard deviation of 0.2% again, we see only a 3% chance of falling below 40.5%. However, we must factor in the tendency for mean-reversion and quality of the most recent polls that have biased the results. 538 handles quality evaluation, but we see some potential slight bias from YouGov. In addition, it's hard to see much good news being released in the next few days, especially as the stimulus bill sees additional delays. We add a 22% chance of reversion outside of normal statistical behavior, and arrive at a final probability of 25%

This fluctuation can be viewed as a random walk with moves of about 2%. Rising above 40.5% in the next 7 days would mean that a two move end above current position. I would also put a slightly higher probability of moving down than up, given the severity of the coronavirus outbreak, the tumbling of the job market, the volatility of the stock market, and the push to open an economy with consumer dissuasion abound. This probability is only slight because Trump supporters have proven without fail their loyalty. I'll put this at 60% probability down versus up in the random walk. So this can be approximated as being about 3.5/2.5=1.4 std above mean in a normal dist, which is about 90%.

For my baseline, I looked at what FiveThirtyEight's 90% confidence interval predicted as of today, and assuming the interval is somewhat normally distributed, I decided that it gave me a baseline of about 50% (since 54% was around 1.645 s.d.'s). This wasn't that useful, so I looked for indicators of Trump's approval among the population in the next few weeks. Based on my research, I think that the two key factors to pay attention to are the announcement of a potential covid vaccine and his poll numbers versus Biden. The first, while not directly related to him, has been a huge potential catalyst for his campaign that would be spun into a story about how he will curb the rising cases and reopen the economy, all good news for him. However, the chance of good news being released in the next week or so is low given all the information being released already. Second, his poll numbers have been steadily declining, which many of his followers openly remarking (both publicly in media and in polls) that his handling of covid is poor. However, it has been remarked that the 40% approval line is one that he's been defiantly above since early 2018, failing to fall below it since then, so it would take some major screw up for it to break through. As of 1 July 2020, Trump's approval rating 40.5%. From the relatively stable values of the approval and disapproval ratings over the past 4 years (start of Trump's presidency), it would seem like some mean reversion would occur and improve Trump's approval rating. However, as of July 26 (just 10 days out from the 5 Aug date), we are currently sitting at 40.2%. Given the linear trend since Covid occurred in rising disapproval and losing approval Trump has experienced due to the terribly inefficient administrative response to the virus outbreak, and since we're still in this phase with no immediate signs of turning the US outbreak around, the mean-reversion argument from before is much less important since the cause for the perhaps linear regime is still in place. However, it's also probably a good idea to weight the linear downward trend with the assumption that approval ratings also follow some sort of noisy random walk, given the patterns that are present in the graphs of previous presidents over time and accounting for massive news or global events that would sway approval in one way or another. On top of this, if we also assume just like in the previous 3 years there's an almost "mental cap" setting the lower floor at 40% approval rating (every time the approval rating has dipped below 40%, it has risen back over quickly), the random walk with downward linear drift between 40% and 40.5% can probably be some weighted average of simple random walk movement and approximating as (40.2-40)/(40.5-40) = 2/5 chance of hitting 40.5 first before the lower floor of 40 and weighted with some linear trend, we can say there's roughly a 60% + (100 - 60) * 3/4 = 90% that Trump's approval rating will be lower on 5 Aug. We can maybe further decrease a little bit since there are tail events that might occur, such as sudden vaccine news that would be reflected in the stock market and hence reflected in Trump's rating as well, or there could be an event of US handling covid better than expected in some end-of-month / beginning-of-month announcement in July, Aug. respectively that bolsters the ratings. However, the upside and probability of these are quite capped since it's more likely for people to respond negatively to something worse than expected than to respond positively to meeting or beating expectations, so we'll say final probability of 85%.
